<h2><a id="user-content-introduction" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#introduction"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Introduction</h2>
<p>For analysis of facebook posts on galway, We have used two facebook pages as my source, namely Connacht tribune and Galway Today. We have extracted data for last 6 months in order to look at what news has been trending in Galway for the last few months. Two news sources were used to provide better weighting to news related to storms like ophelia etc which occurred for only a week. Thus, having more frequency of those terms will give them a better tf-idf rank in the code later on.</p>
<p>For now, let us load the required libraries.</p>
<pre lang="{r}"><code># Loading all the required libraries
library(Rfacebook)
library(tm)
library(topicmodels)
library(RTextTools)
library(dplyr)
library(magrittr)
library(SnowballC)
library(sentimentr)
library(ggplot2)
library(ggthemes)
library(wordcloud)
library(stringr)
options(warn = -1)
</code></pre>
<h2><a id="user-content-1-extracting-facebook-data" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#1-extracting-facebook-data"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>1. <h2><a id="user-content-cleaning-the-posts-extracted" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#cleaning-the-posts-extracted"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Cleaning the posts extracted</h2>
<p>The posts extracted from facebook have many missing messages field, different cases in writing, smileys, emojis and special charcaters which are read in R as . These characters need to be removed before any further processing can be done on them.Also, words will be stemmed so as to prevent same words with singular and plural form being counted separately. Here, we have only considered all english words in language option and punctuations have been removed.</p>
<pre lang="{r}"><code>#Suchandra Mandal
# Removing all empty and NA entries in message field of the dataframe of all_news.
g &lt;- all_news[!is.na(all_news$message),]

# Making a dataframe of the columns we are interested in from the previous datafarme
clean_data &lt;- g[,c('message','likes_count', 'comments_count', 'shares_count')]

# Removing unwanted ascii characters from messages before processing
clean_data$message &lt;- sapply(clean_data$message,function(row) iconv(row, "latin1", "ASCII", sub=""))

# Converting all words in message to lower case
clean_data$message &lt;- tolower(clean_data$message)
</code></pre>
<h2><a id="user-content-2-finding-out-relevant-keywords-from-the-posts-to-define-policies" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#2-finding-out-relevant-keywords-from-the-posts-to-define-policies"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>2. Finding out Relevant keywords from the posts to define policies</h2>
<p>We have some 1227 posts in total after the cleaning process. To extract the relevant keywords in order to form policies out of it, we did not want to select the words manually. Instead, we used LDA(Latent Dirichlet allocation) model to classify our posts into different topics and thereby, find relevant keywords.</p>
<p>For LDA model, we have used the library RtextTools. LDA is useful for finding topics and segregating the terms it comes across in unsupervised manner, that is, no previous training is required. The LDA needs input of posts in form of a document term matrix. We have used term frequency weighting scheme here to create my matrix of terms. We have kept 40 as the number of various topics We want to look at. Usually, to determine K perfectly, people use supervised learning from previosuly classified topics data which in this case, we do not have.</p>
<p>Also, in order not to have any 0 entries in our matrix since that will get an error thrown by LDA model, we have calculated sum of the rows of matrix and if any row is 0, that is removed before the matrix is input the LDA model.</p>
<pre lang="{r}"><code>#Suchandra Mandal
# Remove overly common terms

# We want to now remove overly common terms such as galway, etc which are present
# in atleast more than 60% of the posts.
remove_terms &lt;- function (data, threshold) 
{
  stopifnot(inherits(data, c("DocumentTermMatrix", "TermDocumentMatrix")), 
            is.numeric(threshold), threshold &gt; 0, threshold &lt; 1)
  m &lt;- if (inherits(data, "DocumentTermMatrix")) 
    t(data)
  else data
  t &lt;- table(m$i) &lt; m$ncol * (threshold)
  index &lt;- as.numeric(names(t[t]))
  if (inherits(data, "DocumentTermMatrix")) 
    data[, index]
  else data[index, ]
}


# Creating the document term frequency matrix by excluding numbers, stopwords, punctuations etc
matrix &lt;- create_matrix( as.vector(clean_data$message), 
                        language="english", 
                        removeNumbers=TRUE, 
                        toLower = T,
                        removePunctuation = T,
                        removeStopwords = T,
                        stemWords=TRUE, 
                        weighting=weightTf)

matrix &lt;- remove_terms(matrix,.6)
# K is the number of topics I want LDA model to extract from the posts
k &lt;- 40

#sum by each row of the table
raw.sum=apply(matrix,1,FUN=sum) 
# Exclude all 0 rows
matrix = matrix[raw.sum!=0,]

# fitting our LDA model with expected number of topics
lda &lt;- LDA(matrix,method = "Gibbs", k)

# Groups the posts into different topics 
get_topics &lt;- topicmodels::topics(lda, 10)

## In this case I am returning the top 20 terms from each topic.
get_terms &lt;- as.data.frame(topicmodels::terms(lda, 20), stringsAsFactors = FALSE)

# extracting the top ten topics. I chose 10 topics since more than that, the words returned are not much useful or give any context
f &lt;- get_terms[1:10]

# Since some terms repeat across topics, taking a unique of the terms list
unique_terms &lt;- unique(unlist(f,use.names = F))

</code></pre>
<h2><a id="user-content-finding-counts-of-the-various-terms-extracted-via-lda" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#finding-counts-of-the-various-terms-extracted-via-lda"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Finding counts of the various terms extracted via LDA</h2>
<p>Next, we wanted to look at the counts of the terms extracted and remove overly common terms. The overly common terms have to be removed since even though, they are not stopwords, the semantic context they provide is very little. Words such as Galway, will, city etc are repeated in most posts. Thus, a function was written next to remove overly common terms and a threshold was set to remove them. For the current posts, a threshold of 0.6 was kept. This means if a word is repeated in more than 60% of posts, it is not unqiue to some events and is overly common.</p>
<p>After this, we decile the terms and group the terms according to their counts in 10 bins. This is done in order to select the keywords from the different bins</p>
<pre lang="{r}"><code>#Ashfaque Azad
# creating a dataframe which stores the unique terms and a column count which will store the counts of each term in posts
counts &lt;- data.frame(unique_terms,count = 0, stringsAsFactors = F)

# counting the occurence of terms in posts
for (i in 1:nrow(counts)){
  counts$count[i] &lt;- sum(grepl(counts$unique_terms[i], clean_data$message))
}

# Removing count with 0 since only special charcters will be prsent as this is a 
# subset of all messages so there must be 1 occurence
counts &lt;- counts %&gt;% filter(count&gt;0) %&gt;% arrange(count)

#print(counts)




# Putting the terms into different bins based on count
counts$bins &lt;- ntile(counts$count,n = 10)

# Randomly selecting terms from each of the bins.
choose &lt;- counts %&gt;% group_by(bins) %&gt;% sample_n(2)
#print(choose)
</code></pre>
<p>Picking interesting keywords from bins. Bin 10 has least intersting keywords since the keywords which occur in about 59% of the posts will not have much of news relevance. In contrast, bin 1 to 7 have most interesting keywords</p>
<p>The final set of relevant keywords chosen are news related keywords from the count and choose dataframes such as ophelia, storm, crimes, accomodation etc.</p>
<p>In our data, we have likes, shares and comments counts for each of the posts. A field popularity is created with the sum of the 3 fields in order for further processing to form a dataframe which will contain all the aggregates</p>
<pre lang="{r}"><code>#Suchandra Mandal
### set of most relevant keywords as selected from choose and count dataframe 
words &lt;- c('kayaking','investigating', 'crimes', 'damage', 'missing', 
           'crowned', 'garda', 'support', 'football', 'nationwide', 
           'accomodation', 'defence', 'ophelia', 'christmas', 'emergency',
           'festival', 'storm')

clean_data$Popularity &lt;- clean_data$likes_count + clean_data$comments_count + 
                          clean_data$shares_count
</code></pre>
<h2><a id="user-content-3-filtering-relevant-posts" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#3-filtering-relevant-posts"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>3. Filtering Relevant posts</h2>
<p>According to the relevant keywords which have been stored in vector 'words', the posts having the keywords are filtered with the likes, comments, shares and popularity data stored in a new dataframe called posts_store.</p>
<pre lang="{r}"><code>#Suchandra Mandal
N &lt;- 236
posts_store &lt;- data.frame(keyword = NA, Posts = NA, 
                          Popularity = integer(N),
                          likes = integer(N), comments = integer(N), 
                          shares = integer(N))

# storing the relevant posts containing the keywords in a dataframe along with comments, likes, shares and popularity count
k &lt;- 1
  for (j in words){
    for (i in clean_data$message){
      if (sum(grepl(j, i)) == 1){
        data &lt;- clean_data[clean_data$message == i,]
        posts_store$keyword[k] &lt;- j
        posts_store$Posts[k] &lt;- i
        posts_store$Popularity[k] &lt;- data$Popularity
        posts_store$likes[k] &lt;- data$likes_count
        posts_store$comments[k] &lt;- data$comments_count
        posts_store$shares[k] &lt;- data$shares_count
        k = k+1
      
    }
  }
}

</code></pre>
<h2><a id="user-content-4-aggregating-the-data-of-the-relevant-posts" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#4-aggregating-the-data-of-the-relevant-posts"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>4. Aggregating the data of the relevant posts</h2>
<p>using the relevant posts dataset, we now obtain the count of posts with the keywords selected and then inner join with the posts_store dataset to keep count of posts along with relevant posts. Since keywords will repeat for may posts, counts will be repeated too. While aggregating, we need to be careful of that.</p>
<pre lang="{r}"><code>#Ashfaque Azad
# Summing up the posts with the keywords
keywords_count &lt;- posts_store %&gt;% group_by(keyword) %&gt;% summarise(Posts_Count = n())

# Inner joining the keywords count with posts, to get counts in our dataset
posts_store &lt;- inner_join(posts_store, keywords_count, by = "keyword")

# For each of the keywords, arranging the rows of dataframe in descending order of the Popularity of the keyword.
posts_store &lt;- posts_store %&gt;% group_by(keyword) %&gt;% arrange(keyword,desc(Popularity))

# Writing out this aggregated dataset as a csv
  # write.csv(posts_store,"posts_store.csv")


# aggregate popularity of all policy keywords
best_policy &lt;- posts_store %&gt;% group_by(keyword) %&gt;% 
  summarise(Sum_popularity = sum(Popularity)) %&gt;% arrange(desc(Sum_popularity))

</code></pre>
<h2><a id="user-content-5-visualisation-of-the-results" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#5-visualisation-of-the-results"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>5. Visualisation of the Results:</h2>
<p>The visualisations we have worked on are based on:
a. Sentiment Analysis
b. Finding most popular keywords
c. A word cloud based on trending keywords
d. Showing the most popular posts for each keyword as a table
e. Comparison word cloud to show correlated words with each of the keywords chosen</p>
<p>Let's start with sentiment analysis. Here, we wanted to take a look at what are people's sentiments mostly at an average for the posts posted on facebook connacht tribune and galway today.
To do sentiment analysis, we have used the sentimentr package and found the sentiments of people for the selected posts related to the keywords shortlisted before.</p>
<h2><a id="user-content-a-sentiment-analysis-and-visualisation" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#a-sentiment-analysis-and-visualisation"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>a. Sentiment Analysis and Visualisation</h2>
<pre lang="{r}"><code>#Suchandra Mandal
# Using sentiment function to score the posts
s &lt;- sentiment(posts_store$Posts)

# Since each post has several lines and sentiments are given at a line basis in the previous line, I have summarised the sentiments at an element_id level which is basically at each post level
s &lt;- s %&gt;% group_by(element_id) %&gt;% summarise(sentiment = sum(sentiment))

# Storing the sentiments as a separate column in posts_store
posts_store$Sentiment &lt;- s$sentiment


# For the graph, we first need to prepare the data

# Creating a flag called sentiment_type to classify sentiments as negative or positive
posts_store$sentiment_type &lt;- ifelse(posts_store$Sentiment &lt; 0, 
                                            "negative", "positive")   

# sorting the rows of posts_store in order of sentiment value in ascending order
posts_store &lt;- posts_store[order(posts_store$Sentiment), ]  

# convert to factor to retain sorted order in plot.
#posts_store$Posts &lt;- factor(posts_store$Posts, levels = posts_store$Posts)  

# Using Diverging Barcharts to visualise sentiments of people
ggplot(data = posts_store) +
  geom_bar(aes(x= posts_store$keyword, 
               y = posts_store$Sentiment,
              fill=posts_store$sentiment_type), 
           stat = 'identity', width=.5) + coord_flip() + 
  ggtitle("Sentiments of people across different keywords") +
  xlab("Sentiment Score") + ylab("Keywords") +
  scale_fill_discrete(name = "Sentiment Type")

</code></pre>
<p>Observation: From above graph, we can see that people post mostly positive sentiments and positive sentiments far outweight those of negative</p>
<h2><a id="user-content-b-finding-most-popular-keywords-and-visualise-them" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#b-finding-most-popular-keywords-and-visualise-them"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>b. Finding most popular keywords and visualise them</h2>
<p>Based on popularity of the keywords chosen the next bar graph is generated. Here, we use popularity index which is the sum of shares, comments and likes count for all posts under the particular keyword.</p>
<pre lang="{r}"><code>#Suchandra Mandal
options(scipen = 999)  # turns of scientific notations like 1e+40



# getting the best keywords by inner joining the most popular posts dataframe and best policy in order to have the most popular keywords along with their popularity and sentiment values

# The top posts in terms of popularity with respect to a keyword is stored here
most_popular_posts &lt;- posts_store %&gt;% group_by(keyword) %&gt;% top_n(1,Popularity)

best &lt;- inner_join(best_policy, most_popular_posts, by = "keyword") %&gt;%
  arrange(desc(Sum_popularity))

# Plot
ggplot(best, aes(x = keyword, y = Sum_popularity, fill = "#FF6666")) +   
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", width = .6) +  
  coord_flip() +  # Flip axes
  labs(title="Popularity Count of various keywords") +
  theme_tufte() +  # Tufte theme from ggfortify

<p>As expected, words such as storm which has all terms of Ophelia, Eleanor and recent rainstorms are most common followed by support and festival which could be due to the St. Patrick's day which occurred recently.</p>
<h2><a id="user-content-c-a-word-cloud-based-on-trending-keywords" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#c-a-word-cloud-based-on-trending-keywords"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>c. A word cloud based on trending keywords</h2>
<p>Next, based on the posts of relevant posts subset before, we made a corpus object of the posts of facebook and removed all unnecessary words such as stopwords, numbers etc and then plotted a wordmap with 2 options. The first wordmap is based on the maximum number of words to show while the second limits the overly common words by putting a threshold on maximum frequency of the word in posts.</p>
<pre lang="{r}"><code>#Ashfaque Azad
library(wordcloud)

# converting the posts dataframe to a corpus object
corpusdata &lt;- Corpus(VectorSource( posts_store$Posts))

# Removing stopwords, punctuations, numbers and a few words from the corpus
corpus &lt;- tm_map(corpusdata, removeWords, stopwords("english"))
corpus &lt;- tm_map(corpus, removePunctuation)
corpus &lt;- tm_map(corpus, removeNumbers)

corpus &lt;- tm_map(corpus, removeWords, c(letters, 'galway','will','day',
                                        'today', 'city','thursday')) 


# Creating a term document matrix of the corpus
dtm &lt;-TermDocumentMatrix(corpus,
    control = list(weighting = function(x) weightTfIdf(x, normalize = TRUE)))


# looking out the correlated terms for flood
findAssocs(dtm, terms = "flood", corlimit = 0.5)

# creating a word cloud with maximum 200 words shown
wordcloud(words = corpus,
          max.words=200, random.order=FALSE, rot.per=0.35,
          colors=brewer.pal(8, "Dark2"))

# We can also visualise the word cloud based on frequency of words
wordcloud(words=corpus,max.freq = 200, scale=c(5,0.75), random.order=FALSE, rot.per=0.35, use.r.layout=FALSE, colors=brewer.pal(8, "Dark2"))

</code></pre>
<h2><a id="user-content-d-showing-the-most-popular-posts-for-each-keyword-as-a-table" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#d-showing-the-most-popular-posts-for-each-keyword-as-a-table"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>d. Showing the most popular posts for each keyword as a table</h2>
<p>This dataframe was already aggregated before. Just printing out the table here.
The most popular post under each keyword was filtered based on popularity index and displayed as a table</p>
<pre lang="{r}"><code>#Ashfaque Azad
library(kableExtra)
knitr::kable(most_popular_posts[, 1:2], "html") %&gt;% kableExtra::kable_styling("striped") 
</code></pre>
<h2><a id="user-content-e-comparison-word-cloud-to-show-correlated-words-with-each-of-the-keywords-chosen" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#e-comparison-word-cloud-to-show-correlated-words-with-each-of-the-keywords-chosen"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>e. Comparison word cloud to show correlated words with each of the keywords chosen</h2>
<p>Finally, we wanted to take a look at the associated words with each of the 4 keywords we have chosen to display. A correlation threshold was placed to extract the most meaningful terms associated with each of the keywords. As we can see, with crimes keyword we have computer, track, spread etc .</p>
<pre lang="{r}"><code>#Ashfaque Azad
# We selected the 4 keywords for comparison which looked most promising

#Defence
defence &lt;-findAssocs(dtm, terms = "defence", corlimit = 0.3)[[1]]
defence
defence &lt;- cbind(read.table(text = names(defence), stringsAsFactors = FALSE),defence)

defence$V1[1:12]
defencev1 &lt;- Corpus(VectorSource(defence$V1))

#wordcloud(words = defencev1, random.order=FALSE, scale=c(1,0.75), colors = brewer.pal(4, "Dark2"))

#crimes
crimes&lt;- findAssocs(dtm, terms = "crimes", corlimit = 0.4)[[1]]
crimes
crimes &lt;- cbind(read.table(text = names(crimes), stringsAsFactors = FALSE), crimes)

crimes$V1
crimesv1 &lt;- Corpus(VectorSource(crimes$V1))

#wordcloud(words = crimesv1, random.order=FALSE, scale=c(1,0.75), colors = brewer.pal(4, "Dark2"))
#storm
storm&lt;-findAssocs(dtm, terms = "storm", corlimit = 0.30)[[1]]
storm
storm &lt;- cbind(read.table(text = names(storm), stringsAsFactors = FALSE), storm)

storm$V1
stormv1 &lt;- Corpus(VectorSource(storm$V1))

#wordcloud(words = stormv1, random.order=FALSE, scale=c(1,0.75), colors = brewer.pal(4, "Dark2"))
#ophelia
ophelia &lt;- findAssocs(dtm, terms = "ophelia", corlimit = 0.30)[[1]]
ophelia
ophelia &lt;- cbind(read.table(text = names(ophelia), stringsAsFactors = FALSE), ophelia)

ophelia$V1
opheliav1 &lt;- Corpus(VectorSource(ophelia$V1))

#wordcloud(words = christmasv1, random.order=FALSE, scale=c(1,0.75), colors = brewer.pal(4, "Dark2"))

classic4 &lt;- c(defence$V1[1:12],crimes$V1[1:12],storm$V1[1:12], ophelia$V1[1:12])
classic4
classic4 &lt;- Corpus(VectorSource(classic4))

classic4.tdm &lt;- TermDocumentMatrix(classic4)
library(magrittr)
facebook.tdm.matrix &lt;- classic4.tdm %&gt;% as.matrix()
f &lt;- sort(rowSums(facebook.tdm.matrix),decreasing=TRUE)
d &lt;- data.frame(word = names(f),freq=f)


defence &lt;- rowSums(facebook.tdm.matrix[,1:12])
crimes &lt;- rowSums(facebook.tdm.matrix[,13:24])
storm &lt;- rowSums(facebook.tdm.matrix[,25:36]) 
ophelia &lt;-rowSums(facebook.tdm.matrix[,37:48])

# create a data frame
classic.summary &lt;- data.frame(defence,crimes,storm, ophelia)
# scale the columns so that larger corpii don't dominate
classic.summary.scaled &lt;- scale(classic.summary[,1:4],center=FALSE, scale=colSums(classic.summary[,1:4]))

par(mfrow=c(1,1))
comparison.cloud(classic.summary.scaled,scale=c(1,0.75), random.order=FALSE, colors= c('#66c2a5','#fc8d62','#8da0cb','#e78ac3','#a6d854'),
                 title.size=1.5)

</code></pre>
